feedback.Physical object: Excluded — The equation itself is not a tangible object; it exists abstractly.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — The form and structure of equations are human-constructed symbolic conventions.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — There is no bio-mimicry or organic origin involved.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Equations may represent dynamic systems and are not inherently fixed in form or implication.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — Not a load-bearing or physically structural element.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Visibility arises from rendering (e.g., on paper), not intrinsic to the equation itself.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — It is not composed of matter; it is a conceptual structure.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Not meaningfully applicable to abstract representations.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Equations are intentionally designed to express relationships and constraints.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — An equation itself does not generate a signal or effect outside of its interpretation.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — It represents logic, but does not act or process autonomously.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — Static by nature unless interpreted or manipulated externally.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Included — Created for and used by humans to convey or derive meaning.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Included — Exists within mathematical, scientific, or logical frameworks.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Requires external interpretation or manipulation to be active.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — While often important, it is not irreducibly essential to any one system.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Its function is explicitly symbolic; it stands in for relationships or models.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Equations convey formal meaning via symbolic language.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Their validity and interpretation are strictly governed by mathematical rules.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Equations can contain nested expressions and subcomponents (modular structure).
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Excluded — Not designed to guide behavior directly (like laws or instructions).
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — Some equations are, but this is not typical or essential.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Most equations are atemporal unless modeling time explicitly.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Meaning may change based on symbolic context, domain assumptions, or notation system.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — The concept and notation of equations are created and maintained by cultures and disciplines.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Meaning and validity arise from being defined within formal systems (e.g., math, physics).
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not identity-bearing or role-specific in typical usage.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — Usage governed by syntactic and semantic rules of formal disciplines.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Fundamental unit in mathematical and scientific education.
feedback.Visible: Included — Commonly represented in visual symbolic form.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Interpretation depends on mathematical context (e.g., `x = y` in algebra vs. logic).
feedback.Widely known: Included — The idea of an equation is globally recognized and foundational.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures the equation as a symbolic, rule-based, communicative structure situated within formal systems and cultural transmission. It is not physical or agentive, but it plays a vital abstract and social role in human knowledge systems.
